bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 26, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas writes about yellow fever cases in Panama, as well as sanitary efforts and political maneuvering.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 26, 1905
div1.opener:
Reed April 6th
Ancon, Canal Zone
March 26th 1905,
My dear Kean,
div1.p:
Yours of March 13th received.
And at the same time my copy of the
Journal containing Reeds report.
I am much surprised at its publi-
cation and cannot see the Secretaries
object in having it published. I hard-
ly think that Reed would publish it
without the Secretaries consent.

I presume that the President has made
up his mind to get rid of the Commis-
sion and allows the report to be pub-
lished in order that his position toward
the Commission may be strengthened
2
If this is not the case and the Commis-
sion remain it seems to me that they
would bounce their Chief Sanitary Of-
ficer as soon as they were able. If
I had a subordinate who gave material
for such a report I certainly should
get rid of him the first opportunity.
So I think I had better wait a short
time before I he make a move and
see just how the wind will blow.

It has not done me any harm down
here with Davis & Wallace. Gen. Davis
for the past six weeks has thrown up
his hands entirely. Gives me every
thing within his power without
3
question or going into details. Wallace
& I have always been entirely in accord.

He tells me that he will be glad to see
me entirely independant and reporting
direct to the War Department and thinks
that I should. And says that I can
count upon him for assistance in any
way in which he can give it.

The Sanitary Department is sailing
along with favorable breezes just
now. The last case of yellow fever
occurred in Panama on the 9th and
the total sick report from all causes
is less than two per cent of the laborers.
I have no doubt that we will have
a few more cases of yellow fever
4
from time to time but I believe that
we have practically gotten it under
controle. Will you please return me
the correspondence with reference to the
Lisbon Congress. The paper on the sanitary
conditions at Panama inclosed with
them was the paper I intended for Col-
llecker. I found a carbon copy which
I sent him.

I agree with Gen. O Reilly entirely that
Army men should preponderate in the
Sanitary Department I will be glad
to have more. I will apply for Stroul
at once with the idea of putting him in
as health Officer at either Colon or Panama
till other vacancies occur. Cable received
5
from Col. Weigmar. Shimer I could
use some when on the line. Now about
McCullough & Deverence.

I think that I had better not ask for
any ones relief till I find how I
stand. Suppose I asked for Sprat-
lings relief now. Gen. Davis & Ad-
miral Walker would both oppose.
And I would simply be turned down
and my position considerably weaken-
ed. The most important thing for
me just now is to get my status fixed
If possible to report direct to the war
Department & cut loose from the
Governor. Then I can prove with
a free hand. We must certainly
6
hear something definite very soon.

I am glad to hear that our bill has such
good prospects. Let me know when
the proper time comes for writing to
Millains & I will gladly do so.

Remember me most cordially to
Gen. O'Reilly, & tell him that every
“dammed” Jemaca negro on this
Isthmus will be cinchonized unless
the Commission succeed in bounc-
ing me & that very soon. Weather
conditions are very good along
the line. I have not seen a danger-
ously ill malarial case in a month.
We have gotten the line pretty well
7
drained. Have got a thousand men
on our rolls. I know this makes
Gen. Davis sick when he thinks of it.
But I have the old man under hand
when I ask for fifty more men
he simply says approved. Does not
even ask what I want with them.
He is too meek. I am afraid that
he has it up his sleeve for me.

But even if I get bounced now
I will not feel it as I would have
six month ago. We have shown that
a good deal can be done by san-
itation and I think that I have
made it pretty clear that a good
deal more could have been
done if the Commission had used
even common sense. I do not like
the personalities of Reeds report, but it
is true & the Commission know it.
If it does unseed me it will give them
a pretty good jolt which they will
not forget in a long time.

Please remember me to Mrs. Kean.
Mrs. Gorgas continues to improve
report to start back about April
4th
div1.closer: Sincerely your friend W. C. Gorgas.
